messageBody:
There has, in the past, been discussion of the connectivity of any
potential new writing system for English. I'd pointed out the high
connectivity of the Arabic writing system, and someone suggested that
if it's so connective, why not use it to write English? I'd thought
about it, and later set out on a quest to adapt the Arabic writing
system so that English can be written with it. I gave up on it a
while back, but I found a quite suitable font, the perfect one for
this project. I've since then completed my table of Arabic letters,
and how they'd be used to write the sounds of English. I'd be glad
to post it (and the font required to view it) in the 'Files' section
should anyone request it. I also have a sample of 'Nothing Gold Can
Stay' in my Arabic adaptation. Anyway, I've just finished updating
it, so I believe it's at its best stage so far.

Does anyone think it would be a suitable writing system for English?
If some do not like the fact that it's written right-to-left, the
letters can easily be reversed and be written left-to-right. Also,
do you think many people could get used to the fact that most
consonants are differentiated from the others by dots, and used to
writing diacritics as vowels? Or reading/writing without diacritics?

Note: In my adaptation, ah, ee, oh, and oo are always indicated as
letters, and I, ow, ay, and oi are always indicated (either as a
letter/diacritic combination, or as two letters). The short vowels
(the ones not mentioned above; ae, eh, ih, aw, o, uh, eu) would be
indicated as diacritics, or not at all.

There is also the issue of how people of Middle Eastern descent would
look at a change like this, but I won't get into that. If someone
wants to comment on it, however, go right ahead.

Get back to me with your responses and questions.
